reviewText:
I remember at first picking this up on a whim, doing a couple guns, then putting it down for a long while and not really seeing the point. A few months later I decided to pick it up again and put some actual effort into bringing down my times and working on expanding my view of the map, and that was when I got hooked. The first time I managed to take first place on the daily leaderboards was a great feeling, and soon I started to get a feel for the general patterns of the mechanisms, like how similar the CZ-75 and Jericho pistols were internally, which helped decrease my times on both guns as I learned them. I learned that the Colt Walker is easy to take apart quickly, and whoever made the MG 34 can go to hell. Each gun had their own similarities and differences that were fun to figure out and optimize for the best times. Eventually I completed the whole map that could be done without paying (and I even got a couple of the premium guns from credits earned being the champion on different guns).

Anyway, now that I've rambled for a bit, the point I'm making is that this is a fairly satisfying F2P experience. You don't really need to put in any money to enjoy yourself, and frankly the real money options seem to not have the greatest value. Just expect to log in once every hour or so and learn every gun on the map so you can do the quizzes. You should be able to manage at least 3,000 experience every time once you learn them, and depending on how actively you want to log in and do the quizzes, can rack up enough virtual currency to unlock a gun or two every day. It'll probably take you a month or two to unlock everything, and keep in mind you can buy things that are locked behind premium guns through the catalog at an increased price. If you're good enough to earn credits to buy some of those guns, strategically pick the SVD first to maximize the amount of stuff hidden being uncovered if you want to lower the cost.

In summary, for the price of free this game is worth your attention if you like challenging the leaderboards and don't mind investing some time in the quiz system to get the currency to buy guns. It probably helps if you like guns too.

Update:I feel it's worth noting that virtually every single gun added to the game since I originally wrote this review has required premium currency to purchase. Whereas before you could own nearly every single gun in the game without paying a cent, and good play could earn you a couple more of the paid guns for free, now such a large portion of the guns require premium currency that it's forced me to revise my assessment somewhat.

There's still a hundred or so free guns that I expect will remain free, but once you've burned through those, don't expect to be able to continue to enjoy the game as a free player. Of course, you can always go back to guns you do own to refine your times, but there will eventually come a point at which you've done about as much repetition on the same guns as you care to. My suggestion would be to play through as much as you can as a free player (which is still a fair amount of content), then decide if you want to put money into the game. If you do, wait for the lifetime access DLC to go on sale. It'll be more economical in the long run than trying to buy each gun as they come out. You could spend $10 to get the 100 credit pack and not be able to buy all the premium guns available now. So if you can find the lifetime access on sale for 50% off or more (currently retails for $50), that's probably a good deal if you intend to put serious time into the game.

reviewText:
Before I found World of Guns: Gun Disassembly, family and friends would laugh at my ambitions of single handedly taking down corrupt world governments and large terrorist organisations. To an extent, they were correct.

Thanks to World of Guns: Gun Disassembly, I have since single handedly taken down 4 governmenets, 16 terrorist groups, 2 supervillain super teams and and alien race threatening to enslave humanity. Non of this would have been possible if it wasn't for Wold of Guns: Gun Disassembly teaching me how to disassemble and reassemble any gun within 2.6 seconds.
It also gives you the vital information to disassemble and reassemble a Deloreon of the film Back to the Future, enabling me access to time travel in my journy to save the earth from the evils that threaten it. This clearly shows that World of Guns: Gun Disassembly went beyond just giving me the firepower for my new career choice, but also a time traveling super car.

The only down side to the game is that it is free to play, thus allowing many of my enemies to also learn skills that only we of the free world should have access to. Whilst they could also disassemble and reassemble guns and/or a Deloeon, I feel I got greater high scores and was able to best my foes, proven by the fact that you are sat here now reading this review rather than enslaved on a forign alien planet mining precious gems and ores for the formidible Gorlakians that no longer pose a threat. All this is thanks to the skills that I learnt from the game nominated for 486 game of the year awards and an emmy, World of Guns: Gun Disassembly.

Thank you World of Guns: Gun Disassembly. I would not have been able to keep this planet safe without you.

10/10
Would reassemble again.

reviewText: Its a Facebook game thats somehow ended up on Steam. Because of its origin, and the fact that its free, unlocking stuff involves lot of grinding for experience points, which means assembling and disassembling same weapons over and over again. To unlock guns you only need XP, but for shooting range you need XP and you also got to send friend invites! Alternatively you can skip these requirements with credits, which can be earned with most difficult achievements, but even that can be skipped with, you guessed it, microtransactions! Buy credits or unlock stuff with real money.\n\nBut the question is, is it worth playing? The idea is really cool and if guns are your thing then yeah, go for it. The detail is excellent and it should satisfy the curiosity for those who want to know more on how guns work. However, lot of people will probably get turned off by the excessive amount of grinding and pay-2-unlock mechanics before they get to the guns they might actually be interested in. The game goes really anti-grind already after you've unlocked MP5, as the required experience to unlock the next guns keeps increasing and you earn less the amount of XP when you repeat old one's. I'd love to fool around with something like that Gatling Gun seen in the pictures, but I probably don't have time or patience to tear down the same bloody AK again, again and again, especially when I have better games to play which are actual full experiences.

reviewText: World of Guns Gun Disassembly is not a game in its actual meaning. It’s more like an ABC of guns that everyone would like to have at home. Sure, it would be more interesting to have all those guns at home stored in a special place but if you have a very special need to take a closer look at the weapons of all kinds but at the same time want to be safe or simply can’t afford the arsenal – World of Guns Gun Disassembly is your savior.World of Guns Gun Disassembly is a decent and more than successful attempt to create affordable and deep encyclopedia of guns. But not just a virtual book with boring descriptions and history. Well, not that we do not like history, but all that information is available on the web already. We also have tons of videos and tutorials on how to use guns, assemble and dissemble them and how to fire the proper way. But, have you ever seen an application that would allow you to get inside the gun, see how it actually works and assemble or dissemble the favorite rifle with your own hands?To your surprise – World of Guns Gun Disassembly is exactly this kind of software.Once you got your gun chosen, start playing with it. At first it looks like a simple 3D room where you can take a look at the gun from all sides. However, in just a few seconds it turns into something unpredictably catchy.Everything you do is accompanied with simple but nice animation. In World of Guns Gun Disassembly your task is to dissemble or assembly a gun in a certain order. Don’t be afraid – it follows the rules of logic, so even if you have no idea what to do next – start dealing with the most complicated part of the mechanism. In the end you will either appear with lots of gun elements floating in the air or a fully loaded pistol/rifle/shotgun after making it one solid construction from all that stuff.It’s a great thing that you can train your memory by completing challenges both ways. Not only it gives you a better understand of guns but also allows to be more aware of all the small things. I would say it’s a perfect virtual helper for young soldiers and those who want to improve their knowledge in guns.Despite incredible attention to the details, World of Guns Gun Disassembly also has an X-ray mode where you can see what’s inside the gun and how the mechanisms work without tearing it apart.On the top of all the greatness, you can also equip your guns with various accessories and see how they work.  Flashlight, optics and lasers – they all are here and look different on every gun.World of Guns Gun Disassembly includes all the possible weapons starting from ages ago and going up to the modern and popular models. World of Guns is a wonderful experience.

reviewText:
This game has a lot going for it, but also a lot of major issues.

Pros: Very detailed and accurate gun models. Gameplay is surprisingly engaging. I found myself trying to optimize ways to strip and reassemble the guns to get the fastest time. It's pretty cool they managed to make gun maintenance fun in a video game.

Cons: A few...

1. Poor performance. Even on a 4670k and R9 295x2 the game will still occasionally crawl to a halt and stutter. This is probably the fault of the Unity engine.
2. Ridiculously long tutorial that still somehow manages to not explain things very well.
3. Incosistent on what parts are grouped into assemblies and which are counted individually. Sometimes you have to remove individual pins/screws, other times you don't.

Now the big problems:

4. Free2Play mechanics. The game is set up so that completing every game mode and getting most/all of the achievements for a gun will give you just barely enough XP to unlock the next gun. You essentially have to grind each gun until you can do it fast enough to get enough XP to progress. They then offer expensive boosters" and DLC to help you progress faster. No thanks.

5. (Final straw) The shooting range mode is apparently totally broken. I unlocked the 1911 shooting range and after a couple tries managed to complete all of the challenges. However the game did not recognize this at all
date: and when I returned to the map my >4000 XP had disappeared and I was at 0 XP. This is a ridiculous game-breaking bug and is unacceptable in a final release.\n\nThis game is good in concept

reviewText:
World of Guns: Gun Disassembly is a good game in my book.

But first of all: What is World of Guns: Gun Disassembly?

World of Guns is a simulation. Not the Surgeon Simulator" kind of simulation but a rather realistic one. The developers of the game took their time to good use finding information and blueprints on different weapons. They then created and animated the parts. What you do in the game is disassemble and then reassemble them in varying detail. You start of with two weapons after the tutorial. The AK-47 and the Colt M1911. You can partially assemble them (Field Strip)

reviewText:
This game has a great concept but its game play is bad. Learning about how guns work is interesting and taking apart and reassembling the guns is fun but the way the game makes you go about it is infuriating.

I really enjoy seeing how each gun comes apart and how they go back together. Its great seeing how each part in the weapon works together to fire the bullet and chamber the next round. The x ray and slow motion options are great for capturing exactly how it all interacts. This game does present this all in a very nice way. I feel like i have learned alot about the weapons that i have unlocked however, some of those weapons are of no real interest to me.

You must unlock each weapon with experiance you earn from playing the game but you dont earn enough to ensure you will unlock the next weapon from hitting the most common achiements. This mean you need to repeat each test several times and combine with the frustrating mechanics you'll end up hating the game quickly. Additional the weapons are only unlocked following a tree that might see weapons you want to learn about hidden behind dozens of guns you are not interested in.

The experiance needed to advance is earned from getting achievments such as finishing under a set time or not clicking the wrong part. This method would be fine except that you have to wait out each animation before you can start the next part and by default the camera swings around wildly when each part is moved. This all makes it almost impossible to reach the better times needed to get some of the achievements. Additionally, clicking on a part before the animation has finished will count as clicking the wrong part and shut you out of another achievement further adding to the frustration.

Finally, several achievements are require you to have a faster time then other people in the last 24 hours. These seem almost impossible to achieve as there are people who have unreasonably fast times blocking everyone from getting these achievements.

Many of these problems would be resolved by buying the game but I feel it is simply not worth the money for a collection of interactive user manuals.

reviewText:
It's a neat concept, and a potential great learning tool (If some of the inconsistencies were polished out) for what it does... That said I find it hard to reccommend due to a few issues, most glaring of which being the total loss of all my EXP, unlocks and achivments as of this morning.

That aside, it does have a lot of neat guns that most of us will never be able to touch, let alone take apart.  But I would have liked to have seen even more of the oddities.  Like the Liberator 3D printed handgun; designed in 2013.  Or the Nock gun; an obscure 7-barreled flintlock designed in 1779.  It just needs more.  Especially for the $50 unlock-everything-forever cost, and the fact that you can, apperently, lose everything at a moments notice... For no apperent reason.

For now, I simply can't reccomend it.  Losing my stuff was a game breaker.

reviewText:
Most new weapons now cost Credits. Credits are currency which can be obtained through speedrunning and placing in the top 3 dissasembly times for that day OR are bought with money. I reinstalled the game recently to spend my 108K Experience gained through buying the free weapons and completing the challenges, only to find that none of that experience could be used to unlock any weapon available, all costing from 1 credit to a rather large 20 credits.

This game was and in some ways still is a very unique puzzle and memory game, having to remember order of dissasembly and reassembly as well as the individual screws and panels that need to be taken off. The fact that such a large percentage of the game is locked behind a paywall removes my incentive to keep playing. The fact I've stopped playing doesn't even matter to them, if we aren't spending money then we are of no value to them as a community. They've introduced a voting system from what I've seen, to vote for the next weapon model they introduce; this does not reflect the wants and needs of the community, more like the developer's, as they KNOW people will pay for that weapon.

I've achieved the top three in my time and gotten credits before, enough to unlock one of the cars, a Flak Cannon and many other assault weapons, but some people might not be able to achieve something like that, therefore their time on this game will be short.

Overall, whilst the game is free, you won't get much enjoyment out of it unless you actually grind or pay up.

reviewText:
The basic idea of the game is that you disassemble the guns and assemble them step by step. When you have enough XP, you can unlock the next gun.

PROS:
-Very skill based. You need to memorise what parts to move.
-Leaderboards. Very competitive. You will think that you have the best times. Although some people clearly cheat, Noble Empire, get your ♥♥♥♥ together.
-Very engaging mechanics. It's very satisfying to see all those animations.
-Really easy to understand how to play.
-If you are the plenty of time kinda player AND a gun enthusiast, this is the game for you.
-As you get better at the game, you unlock achievements faster and faster, thus getting more XP and more guns.

CONS:
-Slow start in terms of XP. The game requires you to be good quite early.
-Poor variety of music.
-Inconsistent order of disassembly/assembly. You would think you can take that part out. Unfortunately, the game requires you to follow a specific order.
-Inconsistent duration of the animations. Ruined many speedruns".
-Very small parts are hard to spot or don't come with the bigger parts.
-Hidden guns are much more expensive unless they show up in the unlock tree.
-Not recommended for casual players who just want to play and relax and not have to bother with the XP. But that's the life of free to play.

reviewText:
Product received for free

This Game is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Sham and Here's Why:
There are 2 sides to the game:
Side 1) A fun gun disassembly game that helps you learn the various parts, function, and care of dozens of firearms. This is what the game appears to be at first glance, and for the first hour or two of play].
Side 2) A ludicrously difficult game that demands you to take apart entire 100+ piece guns in a certain order without a single error in under minutes if you want to disassemble anything other than the same 6 guns over and over.

If you don't take side 2 and either a) become the quickest virtual gun disassembler in the world (you literally must in order to unlock all the guns, or b)spend $$$ to unlock new models. If you don't do one of these YOU ARE D-E-A-D ♥♥♥♥ED (see stuck with the same 6 guns forever" above). It's all a tease and a cash grab...sadly. This game had huge potential."

reviewText: World of Guns: Gun Disassembly. A simulation based around the assembly, disassembly, maintenance and operation of various types of firearms which allows the user to better understand the mechanics of firearms and teaches the user the proper method of stripping, disassembling and reassembling their firearm, as well as giving history and insight into the design and use of the gun. As a concept, it is a fantastic idea as it allows the casual gun interest to better understand, and therefor respect, the tool that they admire as well as allow the seasoned gun enthusiast or collector a means of virtually disassembling a firearm without risking damaging its real-life counterpart.\n\nAs a gun enthusiast and owner myself, I saw World of Guns: Gun Disassembly as the latter, a helpful tool. However, the sheer tedium of grinding one gun constantly to get to the next, only to grind that gun again, coupled with both the steep learning curve and steep price tag ($49.99 for Lifetime Access"
date: which grants access to all guns

reviewText:
I find this game very addicting for some reason. It's a great way to educate and guide you on how guns operate and what to expect if you want to repair one of your pieces IRL. You start out with only an AK to toy around with and get 2 more for a while with little choices to getting other guns for free. I got 20,000 points out of nowhere though, which helped me get at least a half-dozen more guns to play with.

Suggestions:
Beef up the credits you get for IRL $. Maybe $10 for 60,000 or so? so $1 = 6,000? Maybe $1 for 10k. Some of the dlc is a tad bit overpriced and I'm used to steam sales anyways you know.

More ways of earning Credits like some more game modes if you can think something up.

Text is instant as in no scrolling till it loads completely. Idk if it's an option already but it'd be a great feature.

In the end this is an excellent game to pick up; it's free, addicting and has a lot of content to discover.

reviewText:
Don't really care about the guns. It's just fun taking stuff apart and seeing the inner mechanics at work.
Just look at it as a 3d puzzle game.

The game's main focus is guns tho.
You can field strip them for maintenance, completely disassemble and put them together, and ofcourse do this timed in the game modes.
Apart from that you can also see the device at work, with xray, and slowmotion so you can see each part at work. Oh, and it has a shooting range too.

There's only 2 things I didn't really like about it; the facebook crap of needing x friends and joining the group for a free starter kit.
And the fact that it's supposed to be a facebook game, but it doesn't have any friends ranking on the game modes.
Makes it seem to me they completely did it wrong: They force you to play this with friends, but don't allow to compete with them.

Anyway the game's free, so if you don't like it, don't spend any money on the packs.

reviewText:
Really cool concept, but in order to play with more guns, you need to spend days reassembling the same gun, or throw away some money.

On top of that, the ordering of the assembly/disassembly is wonky. For example, you need to take the stock off the gun before you can take the d-ring for the sling off the stock. Those, in real life, could be done in any order.

My current speculation is that the bulk of the positive reviews come from people that either a) are frivolous with their money or b) take pleasure in marathon-length grinds.

reviewText:
It let me make sweet, virtual love to my raifu as soon as I downloaded it. 10/10 game.

Speaking seriously though, this is a pretty fun game if you're a big gun nut and like admiring all the effort that goes into firearms design. With a bit of tweaking and effort, I could see it working as a wonderful educational tool.

The game has some issues with it's localization, those can be fixed with time. But it's still embarrassing to see these guys misspell 'Skull' as 'Scull' and what not.

World of Guns sits behing the grindfest/paywall model that other free to play games feature. Whether or not that bothers you is a matter of opinion. I would rather have had it as a mildy-priced retail product, personally.

Really, pick this thing up at least once and give it a go, even if you don't like guns it may even pique your interest in them.

reviewText:
World of Guns: Gun Disassembly is a really in depth firearm simulator. Mostly in the way you pull apart the guns piece by piece but there is a firing range and operation mode where you can fire the gun of your choice with different attachments such as silencers, scopes, different magazine sizes and just learn how every single component works with each other. The satisfaction you get when you pull apart and put back together a sophisticated gun with more than 60 parts without choosing the wrong components is probably more rewarding than shooting the gun itself.

The only downside to this game is that it's a bit grindey, but I guess that adds to the charm of getting to know each and every part of the weapon you are disassembling, but it's not too much of a problem for me as I don't really mind a bit of a grind sesh once in a while. Plus I get time to learn every weapon that is in the game instead of just blazing past every single gun and missing out on how they all work.

In conclusion, it's MUCH better than the Google Play and Apple store versions just because of the fact you have full control over the camera. Plus it's a stupidly fun and rewarding game if you're into pulling things apart then putting them back together just to see how they work and operate.

They debug it like ♥♥♥♥ on major platforms like Windows and much much more ♥♥♥♥♥ier on others, like SteamOS. They don't seem to debug it at all on other platforms like generic Linux. I have Debian btw which is very close to Ubuntu and SteamOS. C'mon guys, crossplatform era (even in gaming) started years ago, not yesterday. reviewText:
Being a firearm enthusiast I was hoping to enjoy this but there are several things that I can not tolerate...

Lacking of options; fullscreen set it on my left monitor instead of my primary monitor. The only way around it is to use windowed mode and thirdparty program to make it windowed-borderless ( haven't tested functionality ).

Instead of being able to choose the weapon, ie I have an HK G36 and would like to see how accurate it is to provide feedback to the developers, you're stuck with the AK47 which you have to complete everything with before you have access to the menu then you're forced to unlock the Colt 1911 and complete that before you have the xp/points back to get something else, but the G36 is tens of thousands of points to unlock meaning you either have to purchase an XP booster pack to gain more xp ( $3 for 60 minutes for 2x xp ) to gain xp quicker in order to get up to the level to provide feedback, or you purchase credits or points to unlock or spend ~$23 to $50, depending where you get it, to unlock all of the weapons instantly...

It is also the reason I haven't been able to go shooting since and was hoping to check out the game to see if it had the SL8 trigger system ( some of the springs are annoying to assemble so I removed the lighter" trigger from mine but was thinking of re-adding it ) as an option

reviewText:
This game is awesome! Personally I am really addicted to this game at the moment. Ok first of all it is no real game... It is more a educational software for gunenthusiasts or a training module for your local shootingclub to further your knowledge about the internal parts of a gun and how a gun excactly works. But the game modes wich you will play a lot if you want to unlock more guns are fun (too a degree). I mean it is really not for everyone disassembling and assembling the same gun over and over again (to unlock new guns), but as this is more a tool to get knowledge about guns and how their internals work and the dependancies between those parts, I call that an excellent approach to bring that knowledge to guninterested people and I think it is really the easiest and fun way to learn about these things.

As I have read some reviews about this game myself, I read a lot about grinding in this game. For a game that is really Free to Play I think that isn't fair to say, cause even if it is a bit of grinding, you get full access to each and every gun through playing. If you are really bad at assembling and disassembling, just do it over and over again... you will get the hang to it and score your needed points.
*Every 2 hours you can do a quiz where you just have to relate a black and white silhouette to a gunname, if you know gun's this is a fairly easy method for acquiring a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of points in just 30 sec. (every 2 hours without a hassle).* Update NOW every 1 hour * Kudos to the developers :)

Get that game and try to beat my highscores, it is free to play afterall!!!

reviewText:
General - 9,0
The game allows you to do almost everything the leftists in your country won't (in my country PT - Partido dos Trabalhadores/Worker's Party). As a gun enthusiast I can say it's the best simulator in the genre that I've seen, it's an almost real experience. If you're looking for a random FPS don't download it, probably you'll find it boring, but if you wanna learn the mechanics or practise the disassembly of some of the most known and reliable weapons it's a must in your library. It has a greater educational value than entertainment value, however I do find pleasure on this kind of knowledge.

Content - 9,5
There are several models of handguns, assault rifles, sniper rifles, SMG's, etc. You start with an AK-47 and afterwards a Colt 1911, the other guns you will have to buy, but you can unlock many more with your exp. points. You get exp. completing achievements and logging in everyday. As if it wasn't good enough, you can also disassemble skeletons (got the highest score of the day :D) and vehicles, which I find amusing. In addition there are shooting ranges, quiz and information about the weapons. Models are downloaded the first time they're used.

Gameplay - 7.5
Modes are: field strip, disassembly, assembly, operation, game, super game and hardcore game, each has a description at the beginning. There are also achievements for each mode and world leaderboards for all 3 game modes. If you liked in the first 10 minutes, chances are you'll play for 10 hours in the first day, so I don't have to say it's replayable and addictive. You use the mouse to interact with parts and control the camera, you can also use keyboard for some actions but I don't recommend. Sometimes a different part is selected in game mode and in some modes the camera moves against your will. In most modes you have to wait for the end of the animation to perform an action, that's annoying in timed modes. RMB is a good and quick way to zoom a specific part. Controls could be more precise.

Graphics - 7.5
Models are very precise and some even include a bit of visual external wear (mechanic wear would make a nice DLC), however they only look like plastic. Options are very limited, but they're not very relevant on this game, you can identify any part at all times, and if you don't, there's a caption in the lower centre of the screen for each part selected. There's native AA support and fixed frame rate at 60fps. The game is windowed by default. In general the models look like any good directx 9 game, I believe it's playable even with integrated video cards. Menus could look better. The game hasn't crashed yet.

Overall - 8.4

Current specs
Intel Core I7-4770K at 4.2ghz
Nvidia PNY GTX 770 2gb at 1201mhz
Kingston HyperX DDR3 8gb at 1600mhz (x2)
HP 1TB SATA III 7200rpm
Windows 7 Premium SP1
Sony Bravia KDL-42W655A at 1080p

reviewText: This game is amazing for both entertainment and educational purposes. It's perfect in every way, save for a few flaws. The only issue, is that the flaws are extraordinary in comparison to the pro's. Not only is it basically a grindathon if you rather not put money into microtransactions, but you must have a certain number of friends (which number increases the more you unlock.) in order to play the shooting range courses.. The most entertaining PART of the game, may I add. (No pun intended.) I'd rather have paid at least 10 US Dollars for this game and have the whole thing to myself, rather than have it contain microtransactions and friend-poking. I can't believe I'm saying this, but I hope they make it a retail game soon, as that might remove the microtransaction and friend-needing element. The experience system is neat, as to challenge yourself to beat new difficulties in order to progress, but grinding does not equal challenge. It equals impatience and disinterest. And if you even try to repeat beaten game modes (Disassemble/Reassemble/Operate/Field Strip, etc.) the experience count you get for completion is laughable at best.\n\nFor operate, (COLT 1911.) I got 200 experience, repeated, it gives me a whopping 5. With the wallet-tease IF YOU HAD A BOOSTER

reviewText:
GAMEPLAY : 6/10

This game teaches you many different parts of each guns.

Basically all you do in this game is just assemble and dissemble each part of the weapon.

People who are not familier with guns parts may found this game some sort of a learning program. Tutorial given to you is pretty well done.

Oh you can also go to the firing range to test out your weapon but the major downside is that you need to find friends that play this game too to unlock the mode.

Not only you get to learn,dissemble & assemble guns,you also do the same for human & animal skeleton as well as car parts.

GRAPHICS : 6/10

The weapon detail overall is pretty decent though some parts of the guns is hard to distinguish from the others.

You can choose 4 different background.

Some of the interface look like it came from a Facebook app. Seriously i am not kidding. If you ever try this game then you know what i am talking about.

AUDIO : 4/10

The sound design for the weapon is really bad. You thought for a game that teaches you about guns,it would at least have a realistic firing sound effects.

Soundtrack is repetitive and only contain like 2-3 of them.

LONG-LASTING APPEAL : 3/10

Can't say you have much fun in this game. There isn't much to do rather than assemble,dissemble,testing out the weapon,beat somebody high scores. That all you do throughout the whole game and it get boring pretty fast.

FINAL VERDICT : 4.3/10

If you want to learn about guns,then try this. However if you are looking for a good gun simulators or fun experience then don't bothers since this game is more like a learning program .

A lot of the bonus things can't be unlocked unless through purchasing credits using real cash. So basically what they ask is Please Give Us Money.

You can get 20 credits by doing offers though but that consist of inviting your friends to play this game. If none of your friends play this game then your chances of unlocking other weapons or modes is 0.

GRADE : F ( Horrible )

reviewText:
Now granted, this is the first day I gave this game a try, but I got 6 hours clocked already. Unlocked several firearms, and getting to know their inner workings is a blast! I'll try to keep this spoiler free if you're looking forward to finding out all the different firearms you can get, like I am. It's A LOT of fun, and is THE game to get for gun owners who find legitimate enjoyment in disassembling/cleaning their firearms. Truth be told, I've managed to completely disassemble/reassemble my Springfield Armoury M1911A1 Mil Spec while blindfolded without using tools within 30 minutes flat. The only things I didn't muck with is the sights, the barrel link, and the... tail thing on the hammer. That's right, I even took out the mag release spring and screw, without the use of my eyes lol Anyways, back to the game... if you always wanted to learn how firearms function, how their individual pieces come together to form one cohesive tool, this is the perfect game for you.

I've never played anything like it, but I've wanted a game like this for years, possibly a decade. The closest thing I remember is a flash game on Newgrounds that allows you to eject the mag, replace the mag, rack the slide, and fire. Not at anything in particular, just to operate the firearm. Of course this has that, and LOADS more. I'm only 6 hours in, I've unlocked a fair number of firearms, and the ones that I'm seeing that are possible to unlock I'm very much looking forward to!

Here's where some of the *SPOILERS* start to come in, but they're mild, I won't mention any other firearms yet, I'll give a warning before I have a nerdgasm on that. There's a leaderboard for disassembly/reassembly time, and there's also some shooting ranges. The firearms will behave quite realistically with mag+1, select fire, and all that good stuff. The only way I could see it being better is if you could adjust the sights, if the controls to reload were more like Receiver, and if you used individual mags instead of the typicall 'ammo pool' that you'll find on CoD and Battlefield. Alright, now to talk about firearms next, so if you want that to remain a surprise, divert your eyes now lol

You start out with the AK47, how appropriate is that? Known for being simple, it's still got some complexity when it comes down to knowing which parts to remove first. Still, VERY enjoyable learning about every last individual part and how they all interact. Next was the M1911A1 (Called Colt 1911 unfortunately. I mean it's a Colt, but it's an M1911A1, not a 1911), and other than the barrel link not dropping before coming out of the slide, as well as the way the hammer assembly needs to be strictly removed AFTER the leaf spring (which is simply nonsense), it's 100% accurate to real life. After that you get the option to unlock the MP5 or Tech-9 if memory serves correctly, and branching off those are the Beretta 92 and CZ75 respectively.

The Tech-9 is surprisingly simple, while the MP5 is DEFINITELY more complex. Now both the M92 and CZ75B are complex in their own right, but I found the Beretta to be particularly unforgiving with its hoard of tiny spring/plugs/pins. Then again, I also had to replace the trigger return spring on my 1982 CZ75 Pre-B so that kind of gave me a hand in figuring it out, came pretty naturally. There are also some historic gems, I can see the sillouette of the PPSH-41, M1928 Thompson, P08 Luger, and the ancestor that lead to the P08 which I can't remember the name. Borsharte? Something like that.

There's more to unlock after finding those out, and they apparently release another firearm at least once a month! All in a free-to-play game!!! You need to unlock experience however in order to unlock said firearms, and that takes quite a lot of disassembly/reassembly as well as time at the shooting range. Both I find quite enjoyable :P Ah, there's also a firearm quiz that you can take once every 2 hours. It lasts 30 seconds, and you have to name all the firearms you can, at 300 Exp. per model. If you get one wrong, you don't get any experience whatsoever, so be careful with your choices. Last time I played it I got 8, which is 2400 Exp. That's almost half way to unlocking another firearm for me, however they seem to be getting more and more expensive.

Performing feats of speed/precision with the shooting and disassembly/reassembly, are the only other ways to get experience at a convenient rate. Though doing the disassembly/reassembly over and over doesn't give you experience very quickly, neither is doing the shooting ranges over and over. The first time you make the time limit/hit number, you get a good amount, but every time after that is only a morsel of your first reward, so unless you want to spend money buying Exp. or credits, you're going to be doing a lot of quizes/shooting/disassembly/reassembly to unlock those juicy firearm models you're dying to get your hands on. Not that that's unenjoyable, but it does distinctly feel like grinding. Eventually doing it more for the Experience than the enjoyment. So basically what I'm saying is unless you're willing to pay, you'll need patience. I have loads of it, so I look forward to making this my go-to game for the foreseeable future :)

Anyways I think that concludes what I know so far. If you're into the mechanical workings of firearms, then get this free-to-play game right now. No hesitation. If you just like playing shoot-em-ups without really caring how firearms come apart or work, well, you'll have to earn the shooting ranges you unlock in the game. Takes Experience for those too, you see. So far I only have two unlocked, and the next will cost me 8000 Experience if I recall correctly, which is a couple hours worth of grinding/quizzing. Still really fun though, with lots of modes to choose from, and I'm hoping to get some adjustable sights/bullet drop with the longer range firearms :) Happy shooting, and remember, check to make sure your firearm is clear before beginning your field strip or disassemble ;) Safety first!

reviewText:
World of Guns: Gun Disassembly. A very simple game for those who love firearms or want to know more about firearms.

This is not really a game where you have fun compared to shooters or simulators or simulators that are made for the lolz.
This game is educational or an easy 3D source material for those who make replicas, fix guns etc.

The game starts well. It tells you how the game works and what you can do in a very straightforward manner.
The rules are simple. You unlock a model, play the game modes, unlock achievements and receive xp to unlock the next model.

The game modes are: field strip, disassembly, assembly, operation, game, supergame and hardcore mode.
Field strip- you field strip the weapon
Disassembly- you take the weapon completely apart
Assembly- you put the firearm back together
Operation- you fire the weapon, reload it and customize it
Game- you disassemble the weapon and assemble the weapon as fast as you can (there are 3 achievements. Timed I is easy, Timed II is medium and Timed III is hard)
Super game- Like game mode but harder. If you click on the wrong part you lose and you have to restart from scratch.
Hardcore mode- you can make more moves. Example: when playing HC mode with an AK47 you can take the magazine, cleaning rod, top cover, pistol and the cleaning kit apart (located in the stock) in a few seconds. To unlock the hardcore achievement you must take your gun apart and assemble it flawlessly. You can not take things apart instantly. For example if you remove the magazine on some guns you can not remove another part while the magazine is being taken out. You have to wait for the animation to end in order to take another part apart or when putting parts back together.

There are also shooting ranges where you shoot weapons and gain xp but you need xp to unlock them.
In shooting ranges you are given a task to shoot X targets X ammount of times with X ammount of rounds.
The reloading animations look robotic in my opinion but they are better than tacky animations.
Its another game mode but if you want to unlock all of the guns then you might think about avoiding them but unlocking shooting ranges is also good because you can gain xp from them and possibly get credits from them on the first try (if your final score is good enough you might be the top scoring player of the day and receive 1 credit).

And then there is Quiz. When playing Quiz you are given an image of a firearm and you have to pick the right answer.
Sounds easy but if you are not familiar with alot of firearms you are gonna have a hard time because if you pick the wrong answer the quiz is over, you get 0xp and you have to wait 1 hour in order to take the quiz again.
So the best way to play this is to memorize the models or print an image list. If you dont know the answer then the best option is to do nothing because something is better then nothing.

There is also bonus content where you can take cars, motorcycles and skeletons apart. The human skeleton is free but the rest is not. Which brings me to xp and credits.

The more guns you unlock the more xp you need to unlock the next model. Now you get a decent ammount of xp for playing the game modes but after unlocking the achievements you get less but depending on the model and the ammount of xp it requires you get more xp (a 16000xp model will give you more xp compared to a 10000xp model). Credits can be earned if you unlock the champion achievement (you can unlock it by topping the scorebored in the Day section. There is also Week and All time. Theres also highscores for each game mode. And if you lack the ability to think the Day section will show you the top scoring players of the day and yes the scoreboard resets). You also get free xp for playing the game the day after so the game is not that cruel. But if you lack patients you can buy a booster pack which doubles your xp or you can buy credits or xp with your money. 1.99 € for 5000 xp. You can also buy DLC to unlock everything but I have not looked that up very well so yeah you can simply buy all of the models for 50€.
While that kinda sounds like a P2E (pay to enjoy) you can get all the models for free if you play casually.
Casually playing is mini grinding and playing Quiz. When you have enough xp you unlock the model you want to unlock, have fun with it and start mini grinding and playing Quiz until you get the next one.

Graphics- since my settings are set to low to get a lot of fps. I am not going to judge but it looks fine. Not super realistic but good for an educational game.

Music and backround art- the music is fine but the backrounds are not. In my opinion the default backround is the best for me cus the space backrounds look cheesy. If you like the space backrounds go ahead and use em. What ever floats your boat keep it floating.

Pros: educational, no major glitches, fun animations when taking the weapons apart, free and alot of models to check out.
Cons: due to the ammount of xp you need you will grind at one point or another and it does take a while to unlock a new model.

Tips: when taking firearms apart while trying to get the best time disable auto focus in the settings. Leave it on in disassembly and assembly mode for ease of learning.

Overall the game is fine. Its not a mega fun blast. Its educational. 7.5/10

reviewText:
Anyone with a passing interest in engineering should install this and check it out.

I'm not a firearms enthusiast, but if the full game was on sale for $10 or so I would consider buying it just because it really is impressive to see everything that goes on inside these machines. Unfortunately the developers went the (greedy) F2P route and charge $50 (as of this writing) to get all of the content, or who knows how much more if you're a sucker and pay for boosts, credits, etc.

The thumbs up is for the truly FREE AK-47 content, and I imagine the full game's content is equally high quality and probably worth $50 to gun enthusiasts.

That being said, as other reviews note, trying to grind your way to all the content is absolutely out of the question. It just takes an unreasonable amount of time to accrue more XP. So install it, but think of it as a demo. If you like it enough to finish the AK in Super Game mode, then ask yourself if you want to see another 100+ guns at the same level of detail. If you do, then spend the $50 and get the DLC that unlocks all content. Otherwise move along.

reviewText:
Very interesting sim for gun enthusiests.

If you ever wanted to know how that AK-47 featured in so many games and movies works from inside and out, this is for you. In fact the AK-47 is the very first gun available.

You can basically field strip, disassemble, reassemble and operate a large variety of guns. If you think you are good enough, you can unlock the timed competative modes and test your skills against people around the world.

For certain models of guns, there are also unlockable shooting ranges to try for some high scores in target practice.
The shooting range experience won't make you feel like you're playing a AAA FPS, but at least you can test the guns in action.

As of this writing, there are also other things that can be disassembled, such as skeletons, cars ( Including a Delorean ), a motorcycle, and even a tank!

On top of all that, the game is free to play. You unlock guns by earning points ( or credits, explained later ). You earn points by assembling/disassembling, using, or winning timed modes with the guns you already have. You can also earn points with a daily quiz and a referral system. To unlock credits however, you either need to make top place in the best times (daily times fortunately), get the referreal bonus, or pay money.

If you want access to ALL guns at once, or boosters, that's where the money comes in.

I was kind of sad that some of the guns and most of the bonus content (cars, skeletons, etc) required credits to unlock, but I can understand the decision, as the level of detail was no doubt extremely time intensive to reproduce.

You don't have to buy it, but you should definitely try it!

reviewText: Gun Disassembly is basically an interactive encyclopedia about weapons, and not a bad one. There are a lot of weapons to read about, look at and disassemble to the smallest part, but not all of them are easily accessible. For instance, there are some guns, that cost a lot of xp points (36,000 for a simple pistol) and some require credits, which you can only get with real money. What saves this game from being a total grinder is weapons quiz. You have 30 seconds to recognise as many weapons as possible, and for 1 correct answer each, you get 300 xp points, which is a reasonable amount. There are some shooting areas, but I found those to be the weakest part of the game, boring and sluggish.\n\nIf you are a Gun Nut, who's mostly interested in how weapons work, then I would strongly recommend this game, if not,  then you won't find much enjoyment here.

reviewText:
Phenomenal Game/Program, Not Free to Play
For one, it's just great in terms of gun assembly/disassembly. You can take apart a weapon to the very core, every little spring, pin, and bolt can be removed and replaced. You can also simulate operations, i.e., firing, reloading, unloading, etc. Moreover, you can do it in slow-motion, or simply pause and scroll through the footage and frames manually to get an in-depth view.

The texture quality is more than decent; it's not like a realism mod, but you can see every little groove and angle that would be present in the real weapon very clearly. For example, I know nothing about guns, just like them in general, got this, then figured out thoroughly, simply through slow-motion footage, exactly how an AK-47 fires with every little detail.

About Being Free to Play

The   game  is not free to play. The  demo  is. You don't get even a tenth of the full game content without puchasing at least an $8 pack. However, considering you can still take apart a few weapons and run operation demos for free, it's definitely worth the download for anyone who likes taking things apart. It's especially worth the download if you want to educate yourself on guns and their anatomy and functions. I'm already much more fluent in the nature of firearms from the small time I've played.

I'm waiting a while to see if any packs will be on sale, like the 4 cars pack is as I'm typing this, and if I can't find anything soon I'll probably purchase the lifetime access. It's overpriced, but not by much, and I'm willing to spend a bit extra for this kind of content.

reviewText:
Less a game, and more a simulation for people who want to dismantle and resemble firearms. Unlocking new firearms require a large number of points, meaning a user will be spending either a lot of time grinding activities repeatedly, or money on buying credits to unlock more weapons.

While the simulation aspects might be accurate, ultimately, it's closer to image training program for anybody who really wants to disassemble firearms, than an actual game of any sort. In this sense, it belongs more in the software category than the game category.

3/10

reviewText: After reading through reviews, comments, and having my own experiances with this simulation, there are several things I wish to point out.\nFirst, this is a simulation. It doesn't have to meet standards of a game. It can be as boring as possible to get its point across or provide the education it is designed to give. World of Guns: Gun Disassembly is a simulation that is meant to teach you the innerworkings of several guns. That is its objective, nothing incredibly fancy. Too me, it accomplishes this. The developers of this program provide a large quantity of guns, more than any other simulator that focuses on disassembly and reassembly does, and more models are being developed. Negative reviews that state their main point as being This game is boring" don't understand this game is not supposed to be fun. It can be fun if you are interested in weaponry
date: but if you wish to shoot other people or targets
recommended: this is not made for that. I think you should experience this to see if you have any interest in models or guns in general.\nSecond
hoursPlayed: people point out the grinding for a new weapon. There are ways around this. One being an option on the main interface with the weapon trees. It is at the very bottom and is the "Catalog". This allows you to purchase a weapon without having an adjacent weapon on the tree unlocked. This does require more xp than purchasing it when it is able to be normally unlocked. A second way to reduce grinding is the "Quiz" tab at the top of the interface. This opens a 30 second quiz where you have to name a weapon being given only it's silhouette. To succeed
voteText: you must name the weapons with no mistakes. One mistake will forfeit your xp gained from the quiz. You can do this quiz once every 2 hours. A third way of gaining xp is to log on once every day. Each day logged on gives you xp
helpfulPercent: which increases each day. I believe that the xp needed to unlock a weapon should be decreased a little
votesHelpful: which it most likely will be decreased in an update due to public opinion.\nThird
votesTotal: dlc costs are high. This simulation is still growing. The developers are offering you the chance to purchase every existing model
votesFunny: and have access to every new model that is developed. That is extremely generous so I believe that the price should stay relatively high to moderate. I for one will not purchase the dlc because I am dedicated enough to earn every weapon because for me

reviewText:
While it does have a rather disgusting business model in place, the game itself is pretty good.
I love guns and learning useless stuff, so this game hits the spot. It's very educational.

I bought the full pack almost as soon as I started running out of xp so I don't know about the grinding aspect, but it was starting to look really scary.
Now that I don't have to worry about running out of xp and whatnot, the game is very entertaining.
I've learned quite a bit of firearm mechanics thanks to this. Me, I've always wanted to know how some of the weirder looking guns function, and now I do.

Taking guns down is easy, and putting them back is equally easy, but doing so flawlessly and fast takes certain skill.
With closer to a hundred firearms, there's plenty of guns to learn the inside out.

Sure, the graphics could be better, but I see this more as a tool than a game so it's not as important.
If you like guns and useless information, this is your jazz. Buying the lifetime access makes you breathe easy and the entertainment factor skyrockets from the free version.

The game is good, business model is bad

reviewText:
This game is surprisingly well thought out.   The operations mode needs to demonstrate the collider relationships on the safety mechanisms that prevent firing, but otherwise it's incredibly good.



I like the integration with the other games by the company, but they need to use each game's specific achievement names.  (This is probably going to be added in later versions, as it looks like something they just haven't gotten around to yet.)



There is also currently a lack of certain setting features, such as keybindings, camera axis control reversals and resolution control.  However, this is a minor detraction, and likely will be in future versions.

reviewText:
This is a very awesome and accurate 3d representation of guns and how they break down piece for piece. There are several modes of play from a basic field strip to a full on disassembly of the gun right down to the last screw and spring. There is a reassmebly mode and then there are 3 different game modes that require you to do a full disassemble and reassemble while being timed with bonuses for not clicking any of the wrong pieces among others. This game has a large and beautiful catalog of guns to choose from. Everything from Mauser to Glock as well as Beretta, Colt, AK variants, Heckler and Koch, Fabrique Nationale, Walther and many others.

This is a fantastic game for any gun enthusiast. It will make you a lot more knowledgeable about the guns and how they break down. You can also see an x-ray view of how the gun works in real time or slow motion while it is in operation.

If that isn't enough you can also fire guns off at firing ranges as you unlock them. (You must unlock guns as well as ranges) One downfall to this is that it doesn't let you choose which gun to use at the range. The ranges have 4 games which are preset to certain guns.

In the end I don't think there is much to complain about. The game is free, and it has tons of guns. You can compete for high scores with other players and friends. You can learn about all of the parts of the guns, and you can even select an option that allows you to see the names of each and every part.

If you love guns, get this game. You won't regret it.

I own a beretta 92FS and I will say the break down of the gun in the game is 100% accurate to the real thing. Every spring, every pin, every screw. Perfect to a fault.


Rating: 10/10

reviewText:
Great game for any gun fanatic , I personally had fun and i learned alot about guns  but poor buisness  and gameplay decisions ruin  the game .

Pros

1. Game accuratley simulates gun parts and how guns work. With very high detailed models

2. Guns recoil and animations are  realistic.

3. Extremly educational for people who are new to using or learning about guns.

Cons

1.Game is basically ''Pay to win'' or in this case ''pay to unlock more guns'' is obvious that the Devs buy guns license for the content .This perspective is ok but no one wants to pay for content that is supposed to a core part of a game .

2.To progress in the game you need to dismantle every gun part and resemble it . Later on the difficulty increases such as taking it dismantling the gun with out doing a mistake if you do you restart the process . This overtime becomes extremely repetitive and boring.

3. Gun sound effects are quite poor

Verdict- Game is great , but dont expect much unless youre willing to pay .   7/10

reviewText:
I used to play this game back on Kongregate.  As such, I was super happy to see that there is a version available here on Steam.  If you're a gun enthusiast, such as myself, you will find hours of informational enjoyment with this game.

Pros :

- Awesomely detailed and animated models.
- Various levels of x-ray viewing.  ( especially useful during the animations )
- Various levels of slow-motion available for said animations.
- Large selection of firearms.
- The shooting range challenges are a nice added bonus.

Cons :

- Sometimes it takes a while to unlock the next weapon if you dont play every day for the login streak XP bonus.
( Slightly offset by the quiz you can try hourly for which you are rewarded XP for how many weapon IDs you can make. )

Overall :

STRONGLY RECOMMEND

I can't call it pay to win, because winning is simply based off of memory and mouse speed, however grinding is a pain when you already have done the same two guns over and over, unless you want to be a terrorist. Grinding wise, I would simply do each gun once a day so as to not drive yourself crazy over them(and become a terrorist.) Overall, for what this particulary is, 7/10.

reviewText:
Not a typical game.  Should not be one's single area for learning weaponry.  Good to try and expand your knowledge though.   Detail is fantastic.

I am really happy that world of guns exists.  I am not a gunsmith, but I have worked on quite a few guns in my day, done some sport shooting, and worked in a gunshot with actual gunsmiths.  This game does well by showing you the details of these tools and from what I can tell they are mostly accurate.

For those of you who are looking at this to learn more about guns, this is a fantastic tool.  My advice is that you also look at exploded views (I imagine where the devs got most of the info from), do some reading, and most importantly: STAY SAFE AND STAY HUMBLE.  Safety is something that the devs actually try to get across in this game and I love it (I even wish they could take it further).  There have been too many accidents happen by negligence.  If you are around a firearm, but your ego aside, always check the chamber (ALWAYS), and dont do any stupid things.  ...this includes trying to do things like FPS Russia or most games and movies.

I also like the way they try to get you in a method of things.  Its interesting to learn and from the guns that I have personally worked on in real life and compaired them to the game, the processes seem logical and solid.  However I dont like the idea of being constrained to all of them when you are trying to preform some of the other game modes.  Some things do need a process, but  if it all has to come apart a screw on the buttstock and a screw on a sight will typically not have a prefrence.  Just keep your pieces organized, make notes / take pictures/video (ive done it multiple times), and keep working on an area all the way through.  That way you can develop a memory and feel instead of going a bit too scattered.

I dont really like the point system they have to level up to get more modes, skins, etc even if you have the lifetime access.   I paid for lifetime access to skip some of the BS.  Dispite that this is still a good tool to try out and I hope they continue adding features.   From what I understand the gun range could use some work.

World of Guns: Gun Disassembly" is a pretty interesting game:

you can disassemble and assemble many weapons
in the bonus section you can (currently) disassemble and assemble

date:

reviewText:
This a free to play puzzle / memory / edutainment game involving dissassembly and assembly of guns and shooting those guns.  You start with the AK-47 rifle, then you unlock Colt 1911 pistol quickly,  with 3,000 xp you can unlock HK MP5, might be a few more you can do for free.  The store sells DLC packs with a lot more guns, cars, motorcycles, skeletons, and xp buffs so it is Pay to Progress.  If you get five friends on Steam to play game, you can earn 20,000 xp and 20 credits.

There is shooting ranges you can unlock for firing those guns, i guess there is games and achievements you can do at each shooting range.  There is a leaderboard for your times and scores versus other players.  There is games involving dissassembly and assembly of guns.  You can operate those guns while using modes: x-ray, cutaway, slow motion, rotating.

Has Steam achievements, few which are easy to obtain, many requiring paying real money.

The camera movement is clunky and can get in the way on timed dissassembly and assembly of guns.

Try it, you might learn something. Great for those gun toting NRA members.

for more info:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_CWV1pF74Ag

http://gundisassembly.wikia.com/wiki/Gun_Disassembly_Wiki

reviewText:
Played for an hour, now I am become death.
11/10

Really more like a 7/10. It's a fun little toy for gun enthusiasts and hobbyists. So far, there seems to be a variety in the available guns, the accuracy of the firearms seems to be of top-notch quality, and the assembly and disassembly can be addicting. If you're looking for traditional fun, you will probably not find it as what you get in the game is what it advertises. You mostly assemble, disassemble, and learn about various firearms. If that doesn't interest, go elsewhere. There are two other gripes I have with the game. Firstly, if you lose connection to the servers, you're gonna have a bad time. It's not uncommon for me to lose connection which results in me having to restart the game. This is a nuisance and can become frustrating. The second major problem is the Facebook game-esque nature. You unlock things by grinding (assembling, disassembling, and playing games repeatedly) and inviting friends to play. You can also get things like XP boosts to unlock more guns and bonuses quicker. If you're not into having your fun held hostage until you get x amount of friends playing this, then go elsewhere.

Personally, I love it so far.
brb, assembling Kalashnikov

reviewText:
TL;DRHave you ever wondered how firearms work? If so, this is a perfect opportunity to familiarise yourself with gun mechanics... for free!
+ LOADS of firearms, including rifles, pistols, machine guns, grenade launchers, and even artillery
+ Attention to detail
+ X-ray, slow-motion, and other features help you see better how a gun works
+ Quiz
+ Low system requirements
+ Suited both for short (although it may be hard to stop playing) and long sessions
- Steals time like nobody's business
- Inconsistent
- Frustrating and unforgiving at times
- Grindy

REVIEW
World of Guns is a free gun simulator. It lets you disassemble and assemble firearms. Moreover, you can also see how a gun works and, albeit in a few cases only, visit a shooting range and put your aiming skills to test.

The gameplay is centred around, you guessed it, assembling and disassembling weaponry. It relies mostly on memorising which parts to move and when to do that. You can move single parts and the whole assemblies. The downside associated with it is that the moveable parts vary from weapon to weapon and it is very easy to make mistakes when disassembling/assembling. Who said that gun assembly was easy?

Apart from the clue of the game, you can also examine how a firearm works. There are some features which come in handy, including x-ray vision and slow-motion. During the Operation"
date: you perform many actions with the gun
voteText: attaching accessories (flashlights
helpfulPercent: scopes
votesHelpful: etc.)
votesTotal: changing the fire mode
votesFunny: and so on.\n\nThe weaponry ranges from historical (Winchester 1887) to modern-day rifles (TAR-21) and everything in-between. There are well-over 100 guns
commentsCount: including pistols
column16: machine guns
column17: and even artillery. To access them
column18: however
column19: you have to earn it the hard way. You start with the AK-47 and unlock other weapons by spending either experience points or credits. The former are earned by completing the weapon tasks (field strip
column20: disassembly
column21: assembly
column22: operation
column24: super game
column25: and hardcore game) and completing quizzes (one quiz per hour). The latter are either bought or earned by topping the scoreboard in normal
column27: or hardcore games (one credit per weapon). Getting all the guns requires a lot of grinding
column28: but that is to be expected from a free game.\n\nTo sum up
column29: I recommend this game not only to firearm fans but also to people playing casually. Despite being an unforgiving and sometimes frustrating game
column30: it is still tons of fun to play and discover. Furthermore
column31: it can be ran on pretty much any PC. Beware though: a wise man once said that this game should not be played at an airport. Mark his words
column32: for you might miss your flight! A 9/10.\n\nP.S. Please check out my other reviews here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/FinnVArthur/recommended/"

reviewText: This game is essentially a facebook game, and it will probably only appeal to a select few. It's like a memory game with guns, with some sexy firing animations to break up the monotony. There is a lot of grinding, but most of it can be avoided by simply mastering the hourly quizes which will net roughly 1/3rd of the experience required for the best gun each time you take one. The best thing this game has going for it is the developers, who are probably some of the most active I've seen for any game. Just look at the Steam community forums, they respond to pretty much everything.\n\nI would love to see camera hotkeys similar to Starcraft where you set hotkeys to a predetermined camera state and more historical guns (let's face it most of the polymer pistols feel the same).

...What more can I really say? Give this game a shot (pun intended), and I can promise you won't be disappointed!

reviewText:
Very interesting game!
It's free, so there's absolutely no reason for anybody to not try it - obviously, yeah, you can buy things in-game with real money, but it's not necessary unless you want to unlock more things/get more EXP faster (which, again - without paying a dime, you get a ton of content, so it's not necessary).

If you're interested in guns at all, even just a little bit, then this game is for you.  The graphics, while not necessarily impressive, are nice, and the Operation" mode is just outstanding.  Every working part of the gun is shown to you - be it in varying levels of X-ray mode
recommended: you can see how a gun operates from the inside out.  This isn't just limited to one weapon
voteText: you can watch how all of the parts interact to fire a bullet.\n\nAs well
helpfulPercent: the disassembly/assembly modes are pretty cool
votesHelpful: and the "game" and "super game"
votesTotal: and "hardcore game" modes are really fun.  You're not just racing the clock or grinding for EXP

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is one of the most dangerous time sinks I have run into since Minecraft.

I managed to unlock the Colt 1911, the MP5 and the Intratec Tec-9.  After a few hours turning them around seeing how everything works I went for the DLC with the unlimited guns. The M-16 A1 model brought back not-so-fond memories of skinning my knuckles trying to pull out the handguards. I also noticed that the o-rings in the bolt are stacked exactly like in real life, it's obvious that these models went through an insane amount of scrutiny.

What's good:

1. You get to see how most of everything inside works.
2. You get to fire the weapons.

What's not so good:

1. The full weapons unlock should allow hiding all new guns and click to show/hide guns as needed so it is not so damn hard to navigate. It is overwhelming when you see all of the guns up to date displayed in one shot.
2. I wish I could use my controller in the shooting games.
3. The game doesn't explain things, it just walks you through. And sometimes the safeties can't be engaged by clicking on the weapon, you have to click a menu button.
4. Sometimes the fire selectors don't allow all positions, so you are also stuck using a menu button to select fire modes.
5. The only adjustable sight post that moves at all so far is the AK-47. The M16-A1s front post doesn't turn, unless I am doing something wrong.
6. Some weapons should allow movement of the hammer but the model only allows to pull back the slide.

Wish list for the developers:

1. Allow show/hide of items already purchased/unlocked/etc.
2. Allow a visualization of the return mechanism, for example the M16-A1 should show me the gas blow back, etc.
3. Allow sights to move if/when the originals do.
4. Explain a little bit more of what's going on.
5. All safeties, fire selectors, de-cocking levers, etc. should be movable from the model, not from menu buttons.

BTW, hats off to the parties responsible for the game mode achievement for doing things in the right order. It's frustrating as hell, but these being dangerous machines it makes sense to force people to learn an assembly sequence. I have been busting my ♥♥♥ for two long miserable days trying to do the Colt 1911 in order and I keep screwing up because I pick the main spring out of sequence or I click the recoil spring plug when I wanted to click on the recoil spring, that kind of thing.

Overall:

A complete absolute win for anyone that is curious about how machines work. The first time you dig into that AK-47 and you figure out on your own why the auto mode works, you'll feel like a rocket scientist.

reviewText:
When I first started playing this game, which I found by accident, I thought it was a bit too annoying for my taste, but once you start remembering all the parts for individual weapons, you feel some sort of accomplishment when you correctly complete a gun with 70+ parts without mistakes within a certain time.

If you get this game, (It's free so why wouldn't you?), you will need to take into account that you cannot expect to complete this overnight (unless you pay £30 for the full unlocks). You could complete 3 or 4 weapons within the first day, but after that the exp costs of weapons starts to rise, and as repeating games nets you only 10% of the exp, you will have to count on gaining most exp through quiz's (every two hours) and daily rewards.

Some bad things about this game would be you require 10 friends who play to unlock shooting ranges, invite 5 friends who don't play and get them to play the game for an achievement and exp.
And that's really it.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is one of the most dangerous time sinks I have run into since Minecraft.

I managed to unlock the Colt 1911, the MP5 and the Intratec Tec-9.  After a few hours turning them around seeing how everything works I went for the DLC with the unlimited guns. The M-16 A1 model brought back not-so-fond memories of skinning my knuckles trying to pull out the handguards. I also noticed that the o-rings in the bolt are stacked exactly like in real life, it's obvious that these models went through an insane amount of scrutiny.

What's good:

1. You get to see how most of everything inside works.
2. You get to fire the weapons.

What's not so good:

1. The full weapons unlock should allow hiding all new guns and click to show/hide guns as needed so it is not so damn hard to navigate. It is overwhelming when you see all of the guns up to date displayed in one shot.
2. I wish I could use my controller in the shooting games.
3. The game doesn't explain things, it just walks you through. And sometimes the safeties can't be engaged by clicking on the weapon, you have to click a menu button.
4. Sometimes the fire selectors don't allow all positions, so you are also stuck using a menu button to select fire modes.
5. The only adjustable sight post that moves at all so far is the AK-47. The M16-A1s front post doesn't turn, unless I am doing something wrong.
6. Some weapons should allow movement of the hammer but the model only allows to pull back the slide.

Wish list for the developers:

1. Allow show/hide of items already purchased/unlocked/etc.
2. Allow a visualization of the return mechanism, for example the M16-A1 should show me the gas blow back, etc.
3. Allow sights to move if/when the originals do.
4. Explain a little bit more of what's going on.
5. All safeties, fire selectors, de-cocking levers, etc. should be movable from the model, not from menu buttons.

BTW, hats off to the parties responsible for the game mode achievement for doing things in the right order. It's frustrating as hell, but these being dangerous machines it makes sense to force people to learn an assembly sequence. I have been busting my ♥♥♥ for two long miserable days trying to do the Colt 1911 in order and I keep screwing up because I pick the main spring out of sequence or I click the recoil spring plug when I wanted to click on the recoil spring, that kind of thing.

Overall:

A complete absolute win for anyone that is curious about how machines work. The first time you dig into that AK-47 and you figure out on your own why the auto mode works, you'll feel like a rocket scientist.

reviewText: If you like guns, or just like mechanical master-pieces, then this is the game for you. This game will teach you a indepth demonstration of: How to disassemble guns, how to reassemble guns, what all the gun part's names are and how the internals operate and function. There is a firing range for some of the firearms, and also a leaderboard system for if you have a competitive side or possibly just want to see what others have gotten for time wise. There is also a different section of other things such as: Bones, cars and AFVs. When I first tried this game I thought that since its free, it would be sh*t, but after only a few minutes of playing I found that it actualy is a very good simulator/teaching tool. This game has been very beneficial to me, in helping me understand everything about guns and all kinds of different guns, for when I fully enter my career and now have a huge leg-up. I also have now started designing and thinking about making proto-types of firearms of my own design. Overall I would strongly recommend this game, and will actively play this game for a long time to come.

reviewText:
8/10

Not a game exactly, but still fun to play.  Not violent at all really, even thought it does have 8 shooting ranges.  I love the game for it's mechanical aspect, how I can take a gun apart, put it back together, see how it works, and, occasionally, shoot a bunch of targets with it. loads of fun if you're into memorizing things, are a hands on learner, or are just plain OCD (and i'm all 3 :)).  A must-try if not a must-love, and i haven't even bought any DLC to go with it.  For the harcore gamers, I'll have to suggest hardcore mode (a bit obviously) where you have to juggle all the parts at once instead of sequentially.

EDIT: The newer objectives dissuade me from playing the game anymore, since it feels like I got all of my achievement maximizations for nothing.
