reviewText:
So let me break it down. World of guns: Gun Disassembly is a unique 'game' if I've ever seen one.
You start off with a classic Kalashnikova and work your way up to a colt, not much of a spoiler there. but yeah.
The game is all about unlocking things; Field strip your gun to unlock dissasembly, dissasembly your gun to unlock reassembly... Assemble to operation, operation to game, game to super game and super game to hardcore game. You can geuss what the first three are; Operation is using the various features on a gun, changing handgrips, firing it, attaching a silencer or even folding a stock. The games however are a test to see your memory of how to put a gun together, you get bonus points and kudos if you manage to do it without touching the wrong part or taking a hint. On super game and up its instant failure to touch the wrong part and there is no hints.

You might be thinking okay thats easy" well... I've spent a bit of time getting raged at a gun for getting one peice wrong or forgetting what came first. A few times the game screws you over by saying "YOU NEED TO DO THIS FIRST" even though there are other points where you do the same thing and the game lets you.

Example: You need to attach two rods to a plate and put the springs back on. One gun lets you put a rod and then the string on before having to deal with the second rod. But this particular gun needs both to be on.

Its a bit annoying when some guns let you do it and doing it for real lets you do it.

On the graphics end of it. The outside of the gun
date: looks awesome. 10/10 texturing. On the inside though... many parts have 'brush' texturing. This means that they are all are very basic tons of grey and black. Honestly they're just shaped blocks at that point
recommended: a mere representative. No complaint unless your obbscessed with HD textures.\n\nOn the of the guns themselfves. TONS of variety. I find quite a few guns I like in their collection
hoursPlayed: however... I need to sift through alot of guns I don't cary about at all just to get to them. Sure you can buy the starter pack or the full unlock... but whats the fun of that? Well
voteText: i'll tell you: total access. Unless you got alot of time and patience
helpfulPercent: you won't get through this game without paying. Because the awarded points for working with a single gun almost never total enough to unlock a new one. Sure the points increase as you move on up... but the points needed per gun almost quadruple. So it makes playing fairly hard to do. Also you cannot earn any points through the ranges
votesHelpful: I do not suggest unlocking them unless you really like the guns your using alot. Plus its just challenges and not free shooting; you also cannot repeat the challenges once you finish. The graphics for the range also take a plunk
votesTotal: going to CS 1.6 esque graphics. AKA Crappy world textures and okay gun textures.\n\nThere is also another few ways to unlock points (two of them broken for me
votesFunny: reinstalling to see if it fixes it for me).\nFirst is coming back every day. Don't laugh you get a points bonus for coming back so many days in a row; even if you only pop in the grab that bonus. But make sure you come back every day or it'll reset.\nNext method is by joining the group and inviting freinds. I managed to join the group... but now it won't let me invite freinds because the button for it does not function. I have even used the other method in game and it still doesn't work. but this gives you some credits and a ton of XP to use on unlocking guns. But
commentsCount: I can't use it because it's broken.\nLast method is the quiz (which has a high failure rate for me... figures)\nQuizes test your ability to recognize the gun models

reviewText: A great game to those who like guns and want to learn more about how they work. Good graphics, good gameplay, with lots of detail, different modes, tasks, objectives to make you train like a maniac to get the best times and to find increasingly efficient ways to take apart and reassemble a gun. Also provides you with historical information about the guns and specifications, complete with a photo collection.\nGood community, with devs that interact closely with the players to get feedback and to keep adding new content and making the existing one stay stable through bug correction.\nOverall, if you like guns you should try this game, if you just want to learn more about guns, fill your free time for fun, or if you want to try and beat the times of players all over the world, or maybe all of these, this is a game that's not going to let you down! Strongly recommend.

reviewText: Many gamers are running around and shooting with all kind of weapons. World of Guns: Gun Disassembly is all about real world weapons. It is not a violent game. Main part of the game is about disassembling and assembling your gun. There are a lot of different weapons, some with few and some with many parts, and about each month there is released a new one. You can play this free game the way you like. When you are only interested in how to dismantle your weapon, go ahead. Want to know how it works? Use slow motion and cutaway views. But you can also play on time and try to beat the daily number 1 or try to get a place in the top 100. It's all up the you. Disassembling and assembling and operating your weapon is giving you experience points, with which you can unlock new guns. When preferred you can buy the game (not a cheap game, but this week 50% off!), which unlocks all weapons at once. Or you can buy parts of the game like e.g. WW2 weapons. The free game takes longer to collect the needed points for unlocking a new weapon but there are no other restrictions. So why not give it a try! As for me, it's a fun game to play and I can really recommend it. For a free game I give it a 9 out of 10.

reviewText:
Do not allow the name to full you, there’s much more than just “Disassembling” under the hood of this amazing Free to Play game.
A simulator at heart, it boasts an amazing User Interface and an impressive range of weapon functionalities, all while taking advantage of an exp system to purchase future projects, They have also fluidly integrated biology, automotive and military vehicle simulators, although I’ve yet to play those.
Does well in rewarding your knowledge of weapons by keeping track of user inputs and time taken to disassemble or reassemble.
I used to serve in the forces and this brings me back, great detail and time taken for the accuracy of the models.

reviewText:
World of Guns reminds me a lot of World of Tanks in its ''ranking system''. And when I say that it reminds me of World of Tanks, I mean that I don't like it one bit.

In this game you start off with the original ''bad guy gun'', also known as the Avtomat Kalashnikov 47 (AK-47). You have to learn step-by-step how to assemble and disassemble the gun very carefully and as fast as possible to unlock achievements and score the highest scores. However, to unlock a new weapon, you need to earn a lot of experience. For example, unlocking the gun after the AK-47, the Colt M1911, is a piece of cake because it only asks for 2000 experience points that you can easily unlock right after completing most of the challenges on the Kalashnikov, however, after the Colt, the experience cost dramatically rises to 5000 and then keeps getting higher and higher.

With this massive experience cost, the game's grind rises dramatically which turns most of the players away from the game, seeking an easier alternative. The easiest alternative in the game, however, is to open your wallet and pay up. Yes, that's right, to unlock all of the guns, you can simply pay for DLCs. Pay-to-win, anyone?

If you seek an enjoyable game in which you want to access all the sweet, juicy firearms and assemble/disassemble them all, test them and stuff, then this is not the game for you. Please wait for a better alternative.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Its a great game, but the grinding, my god the grinding.\n\nand 50$ for all the guns? nope, thank you.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
World of Guns is a great game if you just want to kill a couple of minutes at a time, but it can still hold up extended sessions too. It's very interesting to see the workings of all the models without having to own them and get a reputation as a murderous lunatic. That, and actually since you can hide parts and slow down time while watching the weapons operate, it gives some insights into the gun that most people wouldn't be able to uncover with equipment they have at home even if they owned it.

The biggest problem for me is that the game is ever so slightly skittish on the virtual currency and clearly tries to goad the player into forking out some cash. This would be no problem otherwise, but I don't want to buy the exp straight out as it's the pacing that keeps the game interesting, nor do I want to unlock weapons directly, for the same reason. The boosters are cheaply done; they only last an hour and are much too expensive. The only real incentive to spend money I see here is stickers and other cosmetics for the guns, which I'm not all that interested in. In fact I find the ability to customize the guns with bright colors, animal prints and stick-on pictures a bit tacky.

Something I could see myself pay for would be a premium version where I can take apart all the weapon accessories I normally only get to see attached in operation mode. The differences between skeleton, wooden and synthetic stocks could be interesting, for example. Or maybe being able to operate weapons with parts taken off (and getting to see malfunctions, dry fire, etc). For the right price I could pay for these features even gun by gun.

The challenges and EXP all bottom out by the time you reach the Sten or the Jericho; you're forced to pay or grind afterwards.

Although a rare occurence, there are a few assemblies that are arbitrarily ordered and confusing.

Pros:

Gun porn and the ability to tinker with guns that you don't have (yet).

Overall:

Play until you reach the Sig 550 or Jericho; this is the absolute limit where the EXP system bottoms out. Any further, and the game requires money or several wasted hours of your time on the other assembly series. Besides that, it is definitely an enjoyable puzzle/educational game.

reviewText:
This game's hard to recommend to everyone, so I won't. I'll recommend it to people who have weird compulsive disorders and like meticulously taking things apart piece by piece, and seeing how it works, because that's all you do in this game. And it's awesome. And it's /free/.

What's not awesome is that you have to invite friends to the game to unlock certain features, and the game really stunts your ability to progress like any other social/casual/f2p game. It's fine, because they have to make money somehow.

On the other hand, if you're willing to take apart the same weapons a few times and wait a day inbetween binging sessions, you can easily get enough points to progress without spending a cent! Can't beat that deal.

It's great fun if you're super weird and like taking stuff apart; that's pretty much it. Just try it. It's 90 MBs and free. If you don't like it, you can try it and be done in like 15 minutes.

reviewText: Pros: Extremely detailed. Very relaxing. The actual process is exhaustively accurate (or at least aspires to be - I don't own a gun myself that I can cross-check their work with.) If a given part could not be removed in reality without removing another part, the game makes you do it in the correct order. It also forces you to deal with parts so small that they don't initially seem to be there even on a close examination. Plastic" mode colors all the parts differently in bright neon colors to make them stand out more
date: useful in these cases. A competitive element that you can engage or ignore freely - each gun has leaderboards you can compare yourself against. There's also cars and skeletons to disassemble
recommended: although only a handful of each
hoursPlayed: and a motorcycle and two military vehicles. The game includes shooting ranges and challenges to allow you to play with the guns as well as just examine them
voteText: but it appears that not all guns have corresponding ranges. Out of the five I've unlocked
helpfulPercent: only two have such levels.\n\nCons: You start with only three models - AK-47. 1911
votesHelpful: and a human skeleton (under bonus models.) To unlock more guns
votesTotal: you have to either save up experience points or spend real-world money. If you're willing to spend money
votesFunny: you unlock guns quite quickly. To do it through XP
commentsCount: you have to grind. That's slow - I'm seven hours in
column16: and have unlocked just three additional guns. (Keep in mind that each gun I have encountered so far takes no more than ten minutes to completely disassemble and re-assemble - and that's the first time attacking a relatively complex gun like the AK. The TEC-9
column17: clocking in at less than forty parts
column18: took just five minutes total
column19: and judging by the leaderboards
column20: I'm slow.)\n\nWhat's more
column21: guns unlock in a specific order along a tree like a Civ V tech tree
column22: except that it goes in multiple directions. You have to unlock eight guns to get to the Garand
column24: and those eight guns take you in the opposite direction from the Desert Eagle
column25: for another example. You cannot actually see the whole tree to begin with
column26: either. You see the next guns available to unlock
column27: and you can see vague outlines of the ones after that with no names or detail. After that
column28: nothing. You have to consult charts made by other players to plan your unlocks more than two steps ahead. There's also a handful of guns that can be unlocked only with purchased credits. There are often  guns beyond these that can only be accessed by getting through that one gun - so while they're "free
column29: you can't get at them without having paid. Virtually all of the respectable handful of non-gun models are paid-credits only, as well.\n\nConclusion: It's good for killing a few hours here or there, but completionists should be aware that it is impossible to 100 percent this title without paying, and everyone should be aware that what progress you can make is made only at a comparative crawl.

reviewText:
First off ill start by saying I have worked on guns for a little over 6 years now as a 2111 in the Marine Corps. Basically for all you civi's I fixed guns.

This game gets down to the nitty gritty of every gun i have worked on and im pretty damn impressed. What makes this more fun for me is i also get to dissassemble guns i have never worked on and actually seeing how they operate is pretty awesome.Every little spring and pin that the M9 has to make you rage is all there to make it for a realistic experience. I also own 9 different types of guns and starting off with the Ak made me smile from the get go.

If you dont know your ♥♥♥♥ when it comes to guns and dont wanna learn it i suggest you stay away. This is for sure more of a game for gun nuts and people who actually have hands on experience. I did purchase the 10 dollar started pack but the game is FREE!

All thats basically missing is the feeling you get when a M249 Op rod comes flying out the back of the Saw an pushes your two teeth in.
10/10

reviewText:
Looking at this game at first I could not for the life of me figure out how it would be entertaining, to be honest it looked stupid and boring. Boy, was I wrong, it's basically a Puzzle, Memory type of game where you learn how to take apart and reassemble real weaponery. Once I found out what the game had to offer I was hooked. I find it quite good and a little addicting. It's very casual too, hop in for 5 minutes or 1 hour. It's not like most games out there that really impose on your time to get something done.

The game is free, you only start with one gun but it's easy to get points to unlock other guns. So it's NO WHERE near a pay2play. I have around 11 guns now and enough points to probably buy two more guns depending on what I want. I actually feel quite guilty because I have not yet paid for on of the packs the game does offer which are around $10. I mean it's so cool of a game that I'd like to support the Development team.

I don't know if this review will help much but if you get anything from it, learn from my mistake. I thought the game was stupid looking and almost passed it by but once I tried it I found out how great it is. Don't make my mistake.

At the very least yoou can learn how to take apart and then put back together an AK47 Assault Rifle or Colt 45 Handgun :)

reviewText:
Picked this up on a whim and thought it would be a gimmick or uninteresting, especially being free.  I was wrong.

The developers put a lot of work into this game.  The models in-game are based on real world models.  Every part is labeled with it's correct name, down to the smallest pins, rollers and springs.  If you are detail oriented, mechanically-minded, or simply curious, this will be up your alley!

Whether you are a firearm enthusiast or simply wondered how firearms function, check this game" out.  I don't even consider this to be a game
date: but more of a fun educational tool with games on the side.\n\nThere are "pay" aspects
recommended: but only if you want to progress faster or move onto a subject other than guns
voteText: race cars
helpfulPercent: even skeletons

column17: without "hasty" clicks
column18: and without errors for extra points.  It's very challenging (and I'm adept at this using actual firearms).\n\nThe X-ray feature allows the player to see inside a firearm
column19: even while firing
column20: reloading
column21: safety on-off
column22: etc.  This is what I liked the most about it.\nIn the real world
column23: one can take apart an actual gun
column24: learn the names of the parts
column25: and understand the basic functions; but to see the pieces in action (while inside the gun) gives us a better understanding of how all the parts work together.\n\nThe models are pretty good looking too.  They aren't super high res
column26:
but they aren't low-res either.

My only two complaints with this game:
- The way one moves around the gun/parts to get a different angle is awkward
column28: but it's not game-breaking bad...not by any means; just an annoyance at times.\n\n- Some areas of the breakdown and assembly are draconian when it shouldn't be.  For example:  the AK-47
column29: one does not have to remove the accessories pouch from the rifle-butt BEFORE removing the rifle-butt (in real life).  The game penalizes the player if the pouch isn't removed first though.\nThis problem is more of a developer's attitude of "You have to follow MY procedure
column30: even if it's not necessary in the real world".  This is not game-breaking either

reviewText:
Very fun and truly educational game.
when it says full disassembly it really means it. it  does have a field strip as well, but  on top of that it has a full factory service type of disassembly/reassembly wherer you have to get every single little  pin/spring out.
its a tough game, and  as a  person who has  owned and repaired several of the firearms in this game, i can say that it is a very accurate and educational tool. this would   be SO helpful for a gun owner doing repairs, whos  having a  hard time seeing how a certain assembly goes.
its not with out its problems, there are some order of operation- type issues that dont  always make sense, sometimes it requiers that one gun part comes off before the  other, when in real life that is not  really  how it would be.
but im sure theyre probably following like the service manual order when it comes to those things, so its no real  error i suppose.
great game, get it, i HIGHLY reccomend the  Starter pack DLC< NOT the FULL lifetime DLC.  its on sale right now for 5 bucks, it gives  you 15 guns  that are all unlocked and ready for dis/assembly challenges etc. the full mode unlocks everything, and thats  not as fun, if you are goal oriented gamer, it will pretty much Finish the game for you.

reviewText:
Quick Evaluation========
===================
The Game itself has many pro's and few con's, yet the con's make it obnoxious at times.

Pro's-
+MANY Weapons to model and even re-texture yourself
+Support for other languages, this is actually often forgotten
+Supports direct workshop addition, as well as Modded weapon models
+Accurate models *to my knowledge*
+Customizable backgrounds and mute option for music to add [s]dank meme songs[/s] good music while working.

Con's-
-TOO MANY MICROTRANSACTION SECTIONS
-Micro-Transactions lock out certain features that would have been nice to do, as well as easier to buy models etc.
-Confusing Menu screens
-Misleading titles on certain things
=================================
In-Depth" Review-
This game first sparked my interest after seeing the youtuber WarOwl play it

reviewText:
Very fun and truly educational game.
when it says full disassembly it really means it. it  does have a field strip as well, but  on top of that it has a full factory service type of disassembly/reassembly wherer you have to get every single little  pin/spring out.
its a tough game, and  as a  person who has  owned and repaired several of the firearms in this game, i can say that it is a very accurate and educational tool. this would   be SO helpful for a gun owner doing repairs, whos  having a  hard time seeing how a certain assembly goes.
its not with out its problems, there are some order of operation- type issues that dont  always make sense, sometimes it requiers that one gun part comes off before the  other, when in real life that is not  really  how it would be.
but im sure theyre probably following like the service manual order when it comes to those things, so its no real  error i suppose.
great game, get it, i HIGHLY reccomend the  Starter pack DLC< NOT the FULL lifetime DLC.  its on sale right now for 5 bucks, it gives  you 15 guns  that are all unlocked and ready for dis/assembly challenges etc. the full mode unlocks everything, and thats  not as fun, if you are goal oriented gamer, it will pretty much Finish the game for you.

reviewText:
I can't really decide to recommend or dislike. Wish there was a middle option.

So yeah. You can go and take apart guns, put them together, and watch how they fire. Pretty cool stuff actually. You start of with an AK-47, then unlock the M1911 (I think, haven't played in a while), then the MP5, and then you get a branching path that you can choose from. Each gun costs XP to buy, and when you complete stages like taking apart the gun, putting the gun together, firing the gun, using the gun at a shooting range, speed-disassembling/assembling the gun, etc. you get XP.

However, XP isn't HARD to get, it's just...ANNOYING.

The problem with this is that you get WAY to little XP to unlock anything before you become bored. I don't think I made it anywhere past 4 guns (AK47, M1911, MP5, Beretta). To get required XP, you will need to constantly go back and play all of these games OVER and OVER again. It gets boring, trust me.

I GUESS it would be good to buy the DLC for this, but honestly, just trust me, using it for something like this might not be the best idea.

Is it a bad game? Well, sort of. They tried to make it a game, but I feel like just making it an interactive thing would have been much better and I would have given it a higher score. It's really interesting how you can do this stuff, and the guns are great, but since it's so annoying to get the XP needed to unlock the guns, you probably won't get to a lot of them. If they just lowered the XP required or dropped the free to play"

reviewText:
This review is on the free to play base game. Im given an AK47.

These are my first impressions so far.

I dont like how I have to click some things and all the actions are done. I reload by clicking on the magazine, the game does the whole reload action. I want to reload by clicking on the magazine release, then clicking the magazine and also clicking on the charging handle ON MY OWN.

I have to choose the fire selection through the menu button on the bottom left and not on the damn gun. When you click the saftey on the AK it doesnt cycle Safe>Auto>Semi auto. It is either safe or fire (depending on what you selected on the bottom right of the menu.

For a world of guns i need immersion in a simulation, I dont want the game to hand hold me to do certain actions.

Edit: OK im sure people wouldnt want to reload all the time manually, but that is what the reload button is for on the bottom right, that button should be the full reload, but clicking on the gun should be the manual (non-handholding) way of reloading.

Edit2: I DO like the non-hand holding in disassembling the weapon on the disassembly, but controlling the camera is a bit of a pain.

reviewText:
World of Guns: Gun Disassembly, Now Including Reassembly!

Pros: Guns, Controls
Cons: Value, Graphics, Sound, Gameplay

World of Guns has nearly every popular, iconic, and/or influential gun, from the 'Plastic' Glock 19 to James Bond's Walther PP to WWII German Mastchinepistole 40.  Precise controls allow for some quick digital assembly and disassembly with a little bit of practice.

However, watery textures plaster the more realistic gun models and the soundtrack will eventually cause a headache.  The gameplay is repetitive to say the least.  A 'field strip' is about 25% of a 'disassembly', a 'game' is a 'disassembly' and 'assembly' back to back, a 'super game' is a 'game' without misclicks, etc. These games give experience points to buy new models but the cost/earn ratio is exceedingly high, leading to a massive grind.

As of July 2014, Lifetime Access is 50 USD, almost the cost of any new AAA game.  The repetitive gameplay and free information (cited and copied from Wikipedia) seem overpriced.  Nearly half of the game's 'achievements' are unlocked by buying Lifetime Access, so for achievement hunters, this may be a relatively cheap source of satisfaction.

World of Guns: Disassembly, Now Including Reassembly! Over and over and over and over again!

4/10

reviewText:
The thing about this game was that it has so much potential! The detail, the fun and everything. Only 1 thing brought it all the way down. It is that it will take ages (by ages, I mean AGES) for you to actually unlock a new gun.

Getting XP to unlock a gun will take a long time. You can reassemble and disassemble guns again and again, but it won't give you that much of XP. The only sustainable way of getting XP is the daily reward, which is flawed by itself. Everyday, you get more and more XP (100, 200, 500...) until 3000. Think that it will help you out? I thought the same too. But then, after reaching 3000, on day 7, the count restarted to the measly 100. So much for 'coming on everyday and this reward will increase!'

So if you count the daily rewards that you can get in a week, that tallys up to 6800, which at first seems like a lot. But eventually, you have to unlock guns that cost almost twice that amount. So... you just have two weeks of opening and closing the game before you can get to any action.

When I play, I always ask myself, what's the point of having so many guns if you can't even use them? The price to unlock all the guns is ridiculous too. 50 dollars?? You might as well just add 10 bucks to it and get Battlefield 4 or something.

In conclusion, this game could have worked out brilliantly. Only a flawed daily reward system and the crazy amount of time needed to progress brings it down all the way. 3/10 stars

reviewText:
In all honesty i would recomend this game only to people with interest in the operation and assembly of firearms, and to people with a good bit of patience.

I have played the flash version for about a month and have only unlocked 6 or 7 guns. The game requires, as previous reveiws have stated, a good bit of grinding to unlock things. True there is a quiz that you can take every two hours that can be slightly rewarding but if you make one mistake you get nothing and have to wait two more hours to take it again. If you want to pay for  unlocks though prepare to spend a fortune as it is not cheap. $15 may get you 2 or 3 normaly later unlocked guns.

As for the gameply, id say it is very good. The weapons can be fully dissasembled into the smallest componets and put back together again. There is a wide variety of weapons to unlock ranging from a flint lock pistol to assalt rifles, SMGs, sniper rifles, machine guns, and even a couple of artillery cannons.

This game is deffinetly a very good experience for anyone who is curiose about the opperation of firearms. As well as weapon enthusiests alike.

All and all for a free to play its not bad. Although it would have been better to have a set price in exchange for all the grinding.

6.5-10

NOTE: To anyone who has previously played the flash version, you account does not go over to steam from what i can see. You will have to start over completly. If you play the flash version do not bother downloading this.

reviewText:
The thing about this game was that it has so much potential! The detail, the fun and everything. Only 1 thing brought it all the way down. It is that it will take ages (by ages, I mean AGES) for you to actually unlock a new gun.

Getting XP to unlock a gun will take a long time. You can reassemble and disassemble guns again and again, but it won't give you that much of XP. The only sustainable way of getting XP is the daily reward, which is flawed by itself. Everyday, you get more and more XP (100, 200, 500...) until 3000. Think that it will help you out? I thought the same too. But then, after reaching 3000, on day 7, the count restarted to the measly 100. So much for 'coming on everyday and this reward will increase!'

So if you count the daily rewards that you can get in a week, that tallys up to 6800, which at first seems like a lot. But eventually, you have to unlock guns that cost almost twice that amount. So... you just have two weeks of opening and closing the game before you can get to any action.

When I play, I always ask myself, what's the point of having so many guns if you can't even use them? The price to unlock all the guns is ridiculous too. 50 dollars?? You might as well just add 10 bucks to it and get Battlefield 4 or something.

In conclusion, this game could have worked out brilliantly. Only a flawed daily reward system and the crazy amount of time needed to progress brings it down all the way. 3/10 stars

reviewText:
If you like guns and shooting games why not get to know the technical details and the mechanical know-how on the vast ocean of guns that are out there... I would recommend this game to anyone and everyone who shares a passion for puzzles, knowledge, guns and challenging games.

It is not your average put your brain on the hook and game away game on the contrary it is quiet opposite. It requires a sharp brain and a very good memory and ofcourse the willpower to learn and memorize disassembling various guns.

On top off that there is several other cool features like a shooting range, quiz and an awesome paintshop where you more or less can unfold your inner Picasso. In the beginning I underestimated the game but have come to find that it has a lot of potential. Hopefully the developers will keep working hard to improve it and stay open minded too ideas. So fare I think they have been and are very skilled!

I rate it 10/10 as it is a 1 off a kind.

reviewText:
I've had fun with this game. However, after playing it for 11 hours, I've noticed a few things that have turned me off it.

1: No way to delete your current progress. This is annoying for me because after leaving it for a few months, I wanted to start again. However, there is no way to do so. At all...
2: The quiz is stupid. You can correctly identify 7 models, get 1 wrong, and lose all those points. Why don't I get the points for the the 7 models I got right?
3: You pretty much need to buy extra points after about 10 hours of play. I'm at the point where I have to grind the same models over and over to get one new gun, which then gives me about 30 minutes of fresh entertainment, before it's back to grind-city.
4: So content is locked off by making it only purchasable by credits, which you can't get by playing the game. Guess what that means? Microstransactions!
5: Whats worse is that there are achivements linked to content only buyable with credits. So to get about 4-5 of the achivements, you are forced to buy credits.

So there's my review. A fun game for the first couple of hours, then you hit grind city and all entertainment is lost.

reviewText: *Rewriting this review after spending some time on it.\n\nAfter sitting down and playing the game for several hours I found it to be an enjoyable experiance. The guns are nicely detailed and you learn quite a lot about each gun functions when it is fired. How ever there are some issues. The Spec Ops feature where yu are ewarded for joining their group and having 5 freinds play the game does not work, I've joined the group and have 6 friends play the game and can not claim the rewards for completeing the objective. Another issue is that any new guns they add to the game require credits, a currency you pretty much have to buy to use on these guns. Sure they run a prmo code to unlock it for free, but they are limited and you have to buy the credits if you want to ulock them. The Exp gain is alright, I wish It was a bit higher, I also wish that the quiz system was worked out better like maybe having a 3 strikes and you lose. Overall I'd rate it a 6/10 pretty fun game, pretty educational, but the Spec Ops being broken, and new guns requireing credits is a bit disappointing. Probably will cgange to a Recommend once the Spec Ops feature is fixed.

to improve your World of Guns experience, get baked.

10/10 chill

reviewText: This is one of unique games I've ever played. This game will teach you how to field strip almost all used weapons. From Pistols to HMG. I'm very impressed. It's accurate, which means the developers took time to learn how to field strip all of those weapons. You can use gamemode" where is shows you how does that weapon work when firing. Amazing. You got some small challanges that you have to do in order to earn exp. points which are used to unlock a new weapons. Very original game and it's FREE. This is a must play game !!!"

reviewText:
PLUSES:
- This game is totally free.
- A lot of guns, vehicles and skeletons - all of these stuff can be assembled/disassembled and tested.
- You do not need to donate to get the item you want. The game currency can be easily increased by getting experience from assembling/disassembling items.
- Easy controls.
- Perfect sounds.
- Competitions and leader boards.
- Steam achievements - which is useless. In-game achievements - which is great because of the huge amount of experience they deliver.
- A lot of details. For example, AK has about 100 details and each of them is named on different languages.
- The weapons' customization (colours, stickers, e.t.c).
- Frequent updates.

MINUSES:
- The game menu sucks... Really

reviewText: I love and hate this game. It is really cool and awesome to see how some guns work. You get to take them apart, put them back together, paint them, and see how they operate! It is really cool! But man does it take a LONG time to get enough exp to get a gun (at least it does to get an M4), so you might want to plan on spending money if you want a lot of guns. The AK-47 and M1911 are both unlocked through the tutorial though, so if those are guns you are interested in then prepare for a LONG and BORING tutorial. So I would say its worth trying out because it is free (unless you want lots of guns fast).

reviewText: Pretty fun at first, then you realize its hard to get points so you replay guns over and over to learn them and buy other guns to take apart and put them back together to get points to buy more guns to do that to. It's not really a game, more of a learning program that teaches you how to build different guns and other packs including skeletons and motorcycles. It is frustrating, boring(after 2 hours), and not really worth your time. It is a unique and somewhat interesting game that i would play a few times a year though.

reviewText:
Like some of the comments say, the game is VERY detailed, so it could cater to gun afficianados everywhere...if it did not have the exp-unlock mechanic.

Want to know what I mean?
MP5 exp unlock req: about 3k
Average exp gain for completeing a gun up to Game: 2.5k
That's 500 xp you have to grind for.

And the next gun? 4k
And the next? 5k.
And some are credits only.

It really feels Pay to Play, for being free...

reviewText: When I first got the game I was a little skeptical but after about ten minutes I was Impressed with it's realism and accuracy. All in all I would Totally recomend this game for anyone who want's a challange and addicting gun simulator.
